description.en: The purpose of the course is to describe and analyse the semiotic paradigm in the interpretation of biological systems, the history and main concepts of biosemiotics, the primary mechanisms that generate sign systems, the origins of semiosis and evolution of communicative processes. Several examples of biological sign systems will be studied in depth (organic codes, endosemiosis, categorization in different levels of organic systems, semiosic evolution). The course consists of lectures, the individual work with literature and seminars.
description.et:
1.	Miks biosemiootika: tutvustus. 
2.	Eluteooriad: hetkeolukord teadusmaastikul. 
3.	T. A. Sebeoki semiootilised käsitlused. 
4.	J. v. Uexkülli semiootiline bioloogia (lühiülevaade, kuna tema tekste käsitletakse eraldi lugemisseminaris) 
5.	Semioosi mudelid: funktsionaalne tsükkel. 
6.	Ch. S. Peirce'i semioosi ja eluprotsessi interpretatsioon. 
7.	Kommunikatiivsed nähtused elussüsteemides. 
8.	Liigid ja kategoriseerimine.
9.	Ökosüsteemi semiootika.
10.	Biosemiootiline mina.
11.	Semioosi areng ja evolutsioon.
12.	Taimede, loomade ja inimeste semioos. 
13.	Biosemiootika meetodid.
14.	 Biosemiootiliste uuringute viimased suunad ja tulemused.

objectives.en: The general objective of the course is to provide an introduction to biosemiotics, together with an overview on the history of the subject, its main representatives, classical texts, basic principles of semiotic approach in biology, and a biosemiotic analysis of particular exemplary materials.
objectives.et: Õppeaine jooksul antakse üliõpilastele ülevaade biosemiootikast, antud aine ajaloolisest arengust ning peamistest esindajatest ja klassikalistest tekstidest. Lisaks tutvustatakse semiootilist lähenemist bioloogiale ning analüüsitakse näitematerjale.

independent_work.et:
In addition to the active participance in lectures and seminars and reading the texts, it is requred to write two papers:
(1) a review of one chapter (out of ten) from J.Hoffmeyer's "Biosemiotics". Deadline - xxx.
(2) a review of the work of one classical author, on the basis of a chapter from Donald Favareau's "Essential Readings in Biosemiotics". Deadline - xxx.
Both papers should be written in a style of academic article. The reference list should include as minimum 3 sources.
